newsitem.title: INDIA: World dry bulk cargo freight dip seen continuing.
newsitem.headline: World dry bulk cargo freight dip seen continuing.

text.p: The world dry bulk cargo freight market is expected to remain weak at least until next year, a top Indian shipping industry leader said on Friday.

"Looking at the overall supply and demand position in the world today, I personally feel that the market is unlikely to pick up until 1998," said K.M. Sheth, chairman of the Great Eastern Shipping Company Ltd and former president of the Indian Shipowners' Association (INSA).
"The demand has gone up but the supply is much more," he said. "The market will just keep on going at the level that it is prevailing with a few points up or down every day."
He said he was unable to give any figures.
Sheth said a number of shipping companies the world over had placed orders two years ago when shipbuilding costs were low.
"They are all bunching up. The deliveries of all those orders are now coming out of the shipyards and that's what has increased the supply," he told Reuters in an interview.
According to industry sources, nearly 390 ships are expected to be delivered between now and the first half of 1999.
"The market will remain depressed in the remaining part of 1997 and the early part of 1998," Sheth said.
"But, on the other hand, the tanker freight market is very firm. Up to the middle of 1999 or the second half of 1999 I see the tanker market remaining quite firm," he said.
The Great Eastern Shipping Company Ltd is India's biggest private sector shipping firm and owns 46 ships.
